{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/government-cops-respond-to-marlene-mcdonald-s-arrest/article_b8221798-b9e4-11e9-8bc6-afafcc864fa6.html", "TITLE": " Government, cops respond to Marlene McDonald's arrest ", "DATE": "21 hrs ago ", "CONTENT": "Port of Spain South MP Marlene McDonald FLASHBACK: Newly appointed Minister of Public Utilities Marlene McDonald is congratulated by, from left, close friend Michael Carew, Jean Elder, chairman of the Port of Spain South Constituency, Port of Spain \u201ccommunity leader\u201d Cedric (Burkie) Burke, Kenroy Dopwell and Sharon Felix at President's House, St Ann's, after she was sworn in. \u2013Photo: CURTIS CHASE Minister of Public Administration, Marlene McDonald MP Marelene McDonald's constituency office. {{description}} Email notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items. Port of Spain South MP Marlene McDonald Government this afternoon acknowledged for the first time the police investigation involving Public Administration Minister Marlene McDonald. In a brief statement issued at 2:39p.m. newly appointed Communications Minister Donna Cox said: \"The Government of the Republic of Trinidad and Tobago (GoRTT) wishes to confirm that a search warrant was executed at the home of Minister of Public Administration the Honourable Marlene McDonald this morning (8 August 2019). However, this is an ongoing police investigation and further information will be provided as it is made available by the Trinidad and Tobago Police Service.\" Shortly after the Government's statement, the TTPS issued an statement of its own. The TTPS stated: \"Police officers investigating alleged corruption offences have arrested and taken into custody, Government Minister Marlene McDonald and her husband for questioning. They were detained earlier today, Thursday 8th August 2019. Enquiries are ongoing at this time and more information will be provided when it becomes available.\" At around dawn today, McDonald and her husband were detained. McDonald, the Member of Parliament for Port of Spain South was taken into police custody. The arrests were made at the couple's home at around 4a.m. by police executing a search warrant. The detention came after police went to the Director of Public Prosecutions Roger Gaspard with an investigation file on Tuesday. McDonald, a Cabinet minister, is being investigated on the allegation of misappropriation of public funds. MP Marelene McDonald's constituency office. The Express was told that McDonald, complained of feeling unwell and was treated at hospital. On June 1, 2017, Prime Minister Dr Keith Rowley advised then President Anthony Carmona to revoke the appointment of McDonald who was then Minister in the Ministry of Public Utilities. Minister of Public Administration, Marlene McDonald McDonald had only recently been sworn in as Minister in the Ministry of Public Utilities after a sixteen month period of absence from the Cabinet. Why was MacDonald fired then? McDonald met with Prime Minister Dr Keith Rowley the morning of her firing, as a result of the controversy caused by her choice of guests attending her swearing-in ceremony at the President's House in St Ann's days before. The commotion surrounds the presence of reputed \"community leader\" Cedric \"Burkie\" Burke, who accompanied contractor Kenroy Dopwell to the event. Senior elements of the national security community had expressed alarm at the presence of Burke, who has been engaging their attention. FLASHBACK: Newly appointed Minister of Public Utilities Marlene McDonald is congratulated by, from left, close friend Michael Carew, Jean Elder, chairman of the Port of Spain South Constituency, Port of Spain \u201ccommunity leader\u201d Cedric (Burkie) Burke, Kenroy Dopwell and Sharon Felix at President's House, St Ann's, after she was sworn in. \u2013Photo: CURTIS CHASE Not only was he present, but Burke was introduced by her to the President and posed for pictures with Carmona Carmona. On August 2, Rowley reappointed McDonald, to the post of Minister of Public Administration. Burke was detained on Monday by police who seized his electronic devices including cell phones and laptops. He was questioned and released on Wednesday morning. Reporting by Alexander Bruzual Police need help in locating 16-year-old Shakira Moore. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/griffith-women-forging-ahead-in-it-industry/article_5f7c00da-4910-5f46-a02e-8fdb30416aa6.html", "TITLE": " Griffith: Women forging ahead in IT industry ", "DATE": "May 24, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "JOURNEY OF CHANGE: Rupert T Griffith JOURNEY OF CHANGE: Rupert T Griffith Minister of Science and Technology Rupert T Griffith has said young women will join their male counterparts in effecting transformation as active participants and flourishing contributors in the digital economy premised on their pursuit of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) careers like scientists, aeronautical engineers and business innovators. He also said the presence of about 350 pupils from 14 schools including Tobago was an indication curriculum areas including Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) will soon experience a transformation. He spoke last Wednesday at the Second Women and Girls in ICT Forum at the National Academy for the Performing Arts (NAPA), Port of Spain. The pupils listened to motivational speakers and they visited a plethora of booths where they got informative literature and paraphernalia. Griffith said: \"We are already on the journey of change. You have bolstered my resolve to do even more, because I recognise what we do and what we are trying to advance is neither useless nor insignificant. But rather it can contribute to the foundational work required to develop a truly inclusive and modern society. We must be grateful for the opportunities afforded here to pursue education in diverse fields.\" Griffith added: \"Our intention is to encourage and use and apply technology in a manner that will stimulate critical thinking, problem-solving and the development of skills that will help you to absorb new knowledge all your life. I sincerely hope ICT will open your eyes and minds in various ways in which Science and Technology can impact upon your personal life, career, development of your communities and the future development of the country and the world. You are the generation of this Information Age since you are seemingly born with an intrinsic understanding of technology.\" Griffith also said while \"50 per cent of households own at least one personal computer while enjoying access to a plethora of radio and television stations, there was still much to be done\". But he said the nation must rise to the challenge by striving to secure a competitive edge in a world where daily technological advancements reduce today's innovations to tomorrow's antiques. Griffith said: \"Let not our small size or our vulnerabilities hinder our drive for success. Rather we must use our strengths to forge a path in a world that is being made increasingly smaller by information and communication technology.\" Griffith called for a minute of silence as an expression of solidarity with the Nigerian girls who were kidnapped by Islamic militant group Boko Haram and deprived of their education. Boko Haram means \"Western Education is sin\". He also left everyone with the inspirational quote from 19th-century astronomer Maria Mitchell, \"We have a hunger of the mind which asks for knowledge all around us, and the more we gain, the more is our desire, the more we see, the more we are capable of seeing.\" TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. THE arrest of Government Minister Marlene McDonald shows that no one is above the law, Prime Minister Dr Keith Rowley has said. Rowley made it clear yesterday that he was not afraid to take action against McDonald if that became necessary. MINISTER of Public Administration and MP for Port of Spain South Marlene McDonald was questioned for more than eight hours yesterday by Police Service investigators. Oropouche East MP Dr Roodal Moonilal has said the arrest of Government Minister \u00adMarlene \u00adMcDonald may be part of a \u201c\u00addiabolical plan\u201d. \u201cThis may well be a small piece in a bigger puzzle. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/woman-and-lover-beaten-by-husband/article_95c84b6a-bab9-11e9-bf59-e3ee9ed2ca65.html", "TITLE": " Woman and lover beaten by husband ", "DATE": "2 hrs ago ", "CONTENT": "{{description}} Email notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items. A woman and her lesbian lover were allegedly beaten by the woman\u2019s husband after she confessed to an extramarital affair last Saturday. The suspect, a 48 year old fisherman, flew into a rage after the confession and allegedly beat his wife at their home in Charlieville. Police said when the wife called her lover and told her of the attack, the lover went to the house and was allegedly battered by the suspect and his 19 year old son. The suspect and his son allegedly ganged up and beat the lover with their fists and a cutlass, police said. The two women \u2013the 43 year old Charlieville wife and her 47 year old lesbian lover - went to the Chaguanas police station that night and reported the incident to police. Officers took both women to the Chaguanas District Health Facility and they were transferred to the Eric Williams Medical Sciences Complex. The suspect\u2019s wife was treated for minor injuries and discharged. Police said that the lover was severely beaten on the head and face, and was warded at hospital. She is being treated at hospital for a fractured jaw, perforated eye ball, sliced tongue and dislodged teeth, police said. Police said the husband also went to the Chaguanas District Health Facility on the night of the incident. He allegedly told officers that his wife\u2019s lover chopped him with a cutlass on the arm and finger. He received three stitches to the finger and five stitches to the arm. Officers took the husband into custody after he was treated and discharged. The 19 year old son left the home after the incident. Police officers are looking for him. Police said the husband faces charges of assault occasioning bodily harm and assault by beating. Police said the lesbian lover could also be charged with assault occasioning bodily harm. PC Backan of Chaguanas CID is investigating. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/science-fair-a-huge-success/article_6016e0ef-1b33-50f1-951c-0bbd475e2f4b.html", "TITLE": " Science Fair a huge success ", "DATE": "Jul 17, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "MORE than 44,000 persons visited the Divali Nagar site in Chaguanas to view the attractions at the IndiaA Culture of Science exhibition, which ends tomorrow. Newly-appointed Minister of Science and Technology Rupert Griffith spoke yesterday at an appreciation ceremony held at the Nagar, and described the exhibition as an excellent programme. Pupils and teachers attended the function. Griffith applauded the efforts of the contingent from India. He said, \"Science is a great discipline and a great area to study. Look at a career in Science. Everything is about Science. There are many opportunities and while we have the steelpan as the only invention of musical percussion instrument for the 21st century, this was done right here in Trinidad.\" He said, \"I'm sure as young people, as you begin to experiment and as you begin to become deeply involved in Science, I have no doubt that we will have a lot of new inventors right here in Trinidad and Tobago.\" The exhibition was a collaboration of the National Institute of Higher Education, Research Science and Technology (NIHERST) and the National Council of Science Museums (NCSM) in India. Several persons were presented with awards for in-house competitions hosted during the two months exhibition. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/t-t-to-host-regional-meetings-on-technology/article_84caf7ea-8cce-5035-be3a-d86b342861c7.html", "TITLE": " T&T to host regional meetings on technology ", "DATE": "Mar 17, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "CHAIR: Dr Rupert Griffith CHAIR: Dr Rupert Griffith From today until Friday, the Government will host Caribbean Information and Communication Technology (ICT) ministers, senior government officials and high-ranking representatives of the Caribbean Telecommunications Union (CTU) and the International Telecommunications Union (ITU) at a series of meetings at the Hilton Trinidad and Conference Centre, Port of Spain. Minister of Science and Technology Dr Rupert Griffith, as the minister responsible for ICT and president of the CTU General Conference of Ministers, will chair the meetings which include the 26th Meeting of the Executive Council and the 15th Session of the General Conference of Ministers of the CTU. A news release explained that the week-long event is expected to develop the CTU's annual work plan based on an assessment of the ICT trajectory within the region and in the international arena. The opportunity is also being used to develop a regional perspective on key international developments in ICT, and to enhance the delegates' understanding of the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and its procedures. Trinidad and Tobago is a foundation member of the CTU and continues to be an active and committed participant in the union's on-going efforts to ensure the realisation of ICT development in the region. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/scholar-and-sportsman/article_5eac9d38-7c57-5d34-a727-e857a1c8a1bc.html", "TITLE": " Scholar and sportsman* ", "DATE": "Jan 2, 2018 ", "CONTENT": "WELL DONE, SIR: Mandela Patrick, left, receives an award from Gaye Guada, a North American representative of the Valiants Sports and Cultural Organisation, at its annual Christmas dinner at the Gulf View Community Centre, San Fernando, recently. {{description}} Email notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items. WELL DONE, SIR: Mandela Patrick, left, receives an award from Gaye Guada, a North American representative of the Valiants Sports and Cultural Organisation, at its annual Christmas dinner at the Gulf View Community Centre, San Fernando, recently. TWENTY-TWO-YEAR-OLD Trini\u00addad and Tobago national squash player Mandela Patrick has a habit of setting big goals and achieving them. That habit, coupled with the influence of his dad, Raymond\u2014both a former national squash player and involved in information technology \u2014led Mandela down a path that would see him earn the prestigious and exclusive Commonwealth Rhodes Scholarship last November. The current Harvard University senior has always demonstrated an ability to excel at any project he pursues, be it on the squash court where he is scheduled to represent Team TTO at the 2018 Gold Coast Commonwealth Games in April or in the classroom where he has revelled in the fields of mathematics, computer science, and information and communications technology (ICT). {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/promoting-the-use-of-icts-in-agriculture/article_508d1d3d-2bed-5495-87c2-3cf26439f28c.html", "TITLE": " Promoting the use of ICTs in agriculture ", "DATE": "Aug 28, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "DELIVERING HIS REMARKS: Solomon Ioannou, representative of the Delegation of the European Union to Trinidad and Tobago, delivering his remarks at the opening ceremony of the Second Caribbean Science and Agriculture Film and Video Competition. DELIVERING HIS REMARKS: Solomon Ioannou, representative of the Delegation of the European Union to Trinidad and Tobago, delivering his remarks at the opening ceremony of the Second Caribbean Science and Agriculture Film and Video Competition. The Second Caribbean Science and Agriculture Film and Video Competition launched in October 2013 was a huge success and attracted over 80 entries. The focus of the competition was Adding Value to Local Foods. The main objective was to encourage the use of Information Communication Technologies (ICTs) by young professionals in improving the environment for agriculture science and innovation in the Caribbean region. The compelling submissions which were well researched, entertaining, ethnically sound and powerful in promoting agriculture in the region were received from Barbados, Grenada, Haiti, Jamaica, St Kitts and Nevis, St Lucia, Suriname and Trinidad and Tobago. On August 27, a shortlist of 39 creative Caribbean finalists gathered at the Carlton Savannah Hotel for the final judging and awards ceremony. Representing Daniela Tramacere, Charge dAffaires at the Delegation of the European Union to Trinidad and Tobago (EU) was Solomon Ioannou, programme officer, who said, The competition encouraged creative, technology savvy young professionals with a passion for communicating ideas and an interest in leveraging science and technology for agricultural and economic development to participate. Ioannou added, It is our pleasure to support this project which has indeed important synergies with existing EU programmes and projects in the Caribbean. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/indian-science-exhibition-coming-to-t-t/article_bd0d67c8-5d6c-553e-8ae3-8266aac65863.html", "TITLE": " Indian science exhibition coming to T&T ", "DATE": "Feb 19, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "Recently representatives from the National Council of Science Museums (NCSM) in Kolkata, India paid a courtesy visit to the Ministry of Science, Technology and Tertiary Education (MSTTE) at the ministry's head office at the International Waterfront Centre, Wrightson Road, Port of Spain. KG Kumar, NCSM director, and TK Sarpan, exhibition manager, met with Senator Fazal Karim, Minister of Science, Technology and Tertiary Education, to discuss the exhibition \"IndiaA Culture of Science\", which will tour Trinidad later this year. The exhibition will showcase both ancient Indian scientific knowledge and the Indian contribution to modern science and technology. NCSM has staged similar exhibitions all over the world, but this will be the first of its kind in the Caribbean. They will be working in conjunction with the National Institute of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology (NIHERST), an agency of MSTTE. This collaboration started after both institutions signed an agreement in India, as part of the state visit by Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar. Minister Karim expressed his enthusiastic support for the venture, confirming that his ministry will collaborate with the Ministry of Transport to secure buses to take schoolchildren to the exhibition. The exhibition is expected to be held at the Divali Nagar site, Chaguanas. Team TTO rower Felice Aisha Chow continues defying her age, creating history by becoming the first rower from this country to win a Pan American Games medal in the sport when she earned silver in the Women\u2019s Singles Sculls 2000m event yesterday at the Lima 2019 Games. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/technology-in-the-marketing-process/article_3d3443f0-fe1f-5efd-99a5-852be341dac8.html", "TITLE": " Technology in the marketing process* ", "DATE": "Aug 16, 2016 ", "CONTENT": "MARKETING is defined as \u201c...the management process responsible for identifying, anticipating and satisfying customer requirements profitably\u201d (Chartered Institute of Marketing). The Merriam-Webster dictionary defines technology as the use of science in industry, engineering, etc, to invent useful things or to solve problems. Marrying the two in today's fast paced, ever changing environment presents both a boon and a curse for marketers and small business owners who face the challenges of creating the right products and services, positioned at the right price, accessible to customers when and where they want them, and to be able to modify such products and services or abandon them altogether when market conditions change. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/humanities-in-education-can-help-produce-a-more-humane-society/article_2492d55f-9e0a-529e-9ad9-612f868029fb.html", "TITLE": " Humanities in education can help produce a more humane society* ", "DATE": "Aug 3, 2017 ", "CONTENT": "Continuing from my last letter, the theme of combating crime in the long term through critical thinking in the classroom which cultivates a personal culture of interrogating issues before deciding upon them, I want to extend that strategy into placing more emphasis on the liberal arts/humanities in our education. This will include English/English literature, history and social studies and other related disciplines that have long been neglected in our institutions of learning because of the new emphasis on science and technology and vocational education in the so-called age of technology. Granted, such emphasis suits the times in which we live, planners and policy makers have long relegated the arts into this secondary position in the curriculum without fully understanding the important balance which the humanities provides to the \u201crobotic\u201d mindset which science and technology, in themselves, cultivate in our pupils. Let me illustrate with an example from my days at Naparima College as an A-Level pupil. Our A-Level rivals at Presentation College, San Fernando, from the other side of town, were often reputed to be \u201cscience\u201d in orientation while we were condescendingly described as \u201carts\u201d. This programme is part of the ongoing efforts of t NYAC to contribute towards the total development of young people within Trinidad and Tobago and the Caribbean. The programme will highlight the outstanding achievements of young people in Trinidad and Tobago over the past year. Awards will be presented for performances of excellence in various activities and disciplines, including sports, academics, culture, community service, science and technology and the arts. A major highlight of the event will be the performances of our nation's top twenty artistes in various cultural art forms presented during the past year. Some of those awarded in the past include:-Athletics- Trinidad and Tobago Athletic Team (Olympic Silver Medalists); Darren Ganga Cricket; Katija Khan Community Service; George Bovell III- Swimming; Akhenaton Daaga- Youth Leadership; Jesse Boocock Golf; Kenwyne Jones Football; Carus Palmer Visual Arts; Shivana Ragoonanan Music (Pan); Giselle Salandy Boxing; Surendra Surajdeo Maharaj Science & Technology and the Signal Hill Alumni Choir; to name a few. The following are the names of persons who will be awarded this year. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/getting-back-on-track/article_a4e4a6ee-3bc7-5dc8-bee6-1706d1209c89.html", "TITLE": " 'Getting back on track' ", "DATE": "Feb 4, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "The University of Trinidad and Tobago is on a spending freeze. But president and chairman Kenneth Ramchand said in an interview last week that though times are challenging, these were exciting times for the university. Noting that Government has brought in auditors to investigate the financial operations of the university, Ramchand said it was against this background that UTT was re-focussing on its aims and goals and getting back on track. \"The challenge we face at the moment is to win back the confidence of the population and to excite them about what the UTT was intended to be and what we plan to make it become. The vision we have is of a unique institution,\" he said. Citing as examples Ryerson University of Technology, the British Columbia Institute of Technology and the California Institute of Technology, Ramchand noted that the original sciences and technology curricula of these institutions were expanded to include the humanities. \"You'd find that in an ideal institution like this, the scientists go to concerts, see paintings, go to movies, take part in general discussions about life and so on. \"And the artists are always trying to pick their brains about how certain technologies may assist in the teaching process, the writing process etc. It is a synergy, synergies taking place there now that nobody had planned for,\" he said. Ramchand said UTT's intent was to follow a similar path, having begun as a science and technology university focussing on engineering and providing training for niche areas in economic and science and technology fields. He also said two months ago, UTT underwent a mandatory accreditation assessment by the Accreditation Council of Trinidad and Tobago-appointed external team of foreign academics, led by Dr John Randall. \"At the height of the financial crisis as it were, when all kinds of allegations were being made about corruption, Dr Randall and his team visited all departments and made a thorough investigation,\" said Ramchand. He said the team reported no concerns about UTT's fulfillment of the criteria for institutional accreditation, and that students interviewed by the team said that they had selected the university because of \"its distinctive role in producing a more work-ready graduate who is better able to apply industry relevant knowledge and skill.\" \"Our professors are up to that standard. And our students also were found comparable to students in other accredited institutions.They were judging us as an academic institution, and we passed brilliantly,\" Ramchand said. Regarding the university's finances, Ramchand said that while the UTT was involving all staff - academic and non-academic - in the review of the overall strategic plan, the institution had also instituted some cost-cutting measures and was continuing to look at ways of reducing expenses in line with the Board's policy of cost restraint. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/india-s-scientific-showcase/article_dba69e24-b9fc-5bc8-b387-e6763adec321.html", "TITLE": " India's scientific showcase ", "DATE": "May 27, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "caught on camera: Opposition Leader Dr Keith Rowley displays photos of \u0093racist\u0094 placards yesterday which were captured outside the Parliament building, Tower D, International Waterfront Centre, Port of Spain, on Friday. Rowley was addressing a news conference at his Charles Street, Port of Spain, office. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE illusion: Students of Naparima College look inside the Infinity Well. caught on camera: Opposition Leader Dr Keith Rowley displays photos of \u0093racist\u0094 placards yesterday which were captured outside the Parliament building, Tower D, International Waterfront Centre, Port of Spain, on Friday. Rowley was addressing a news conference at his Charles Street, Port of Spain, office. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE illusion: Students of Naparima College look inside the Infinity Well. Squeals of delight could be heard ringing through the corridors of the Divali Nagar site in Chaguanas as excited children of all ages and from various schools across the country came to witness and take part in a science exhibition held by the National Institute of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology (NIHERST) and the National Council of Science Museums (NCSM) of India. The exhibition which started on Tuesday May 22 will run till July 20. The show is open to the public free of charge, and patrons were treated to 7,000 years of India's history and incredible scientific discoveries and achievements. This event is part of NIHERST's programme of activities to foster a national culture of science and technology, supporting the development of a more diversified, knowledge-driven economy in Trinidad and Tobago. Starting at 9a.m., hundreds of children flocked the entryway of the exhibition. Eager little faces pressed up to various interactive displays as they sought to get a closer look. Rei Medford from Naparima College had some of his friends raising their eyebrows as his head appeared to be resting on a plate of fruit while his body was nowhere to be seen. A trick of the eye according to one of the attendants as Medford reappeared all in one piece. The exhibit called \"Head on a platter\" was one of the more popular displays for pupils. Another favourite was the Infinity Well. Scores of children looked inside a makeshift shallow well that appeared to the naked eye as a bottomless pit. According to information printed on the side of the exhibit, the cylindrical wall of the well is sandwiched between two parallel mirrors; a full mirror on the floor and a half mirror on top of the well giving the optical illusion. One pupils who appeared tickled by the display, jokingly said, \"Be careful you fall in, it's a long way down.\" Administrator of the NIHERST National Science Centre Karla Sookhram said, \"The exhibit is open to children as young as seven and also adults. This is the first time we are having an exhibition of this type in Trinidad. Science and mathematics are two subject areas that is usually challenging for many students, we hope that through this exhibition it will stimulate young minds to the world of Science and Technology and encourage them to pursue a career within this field.\" Echoing similar sentiments, Senior curator of the National Council of Science Museums of India, Nataraj Dasgupta, said, \"This exhibit showcases India in ancient time as well as in modern period along with that we have some interactive displays for kids to encourage them to pursue a career in science and technology.\" \"India has a rich heritage in science and technology and this has grown in the field of not only science but also mathematics, metallurgy, agriculture, medicine, architecture and art and textiles. As soon as you enter the exhibition there are two large structures, the Konark Wheel and an Iron Pillar. India has a long tradition of making iron and steel structures and the Iron Pillar is approximately 26 feet tall. It is one of the more interesting displays at the exhibition since the pillar never rusts,\" he said. \"We have a custom in India, if a person is able to put their hands behind their back around the pillar with their fingers of their left and right hand touching then their wishes will come true,\" he added. The exhibition, themed \"IndiaA Culture of Science\", will showcase approximately 150 exhibits, featuring some of India's finest craft technologies such as bidriware, silver filigree work, lost wax casting and marble inlay to name a few. It starts at 9 a.m. and runs to 7 p.m daily and 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. on weekends. Visitors can also experience live science demonstrations, public lectures and cultural performances. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/nursing-student-robbed/article_56c30495-bbc1-55ea-b3d8-8ea5db91a353.html", "TITLE": " Nursing student robbed ", "DATE": "Nov 2, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "A 19-year-old nursing student was held up at gunpoint and robbed of a cellphone and cash on Thursday. Shauna Lee Guada, a student of the College of Science, Technology and Applied Arts of Trinidad and Tobago (COSTAATT) Nursing School, was walking from San Fernando General Hospital when she was attacked at around 1.30 p.m. Police said two men walked up to Guada, of Eccles Street, La Romaine, and placed a gun to her back. The men ordered that she hand over her BlackBerry Torch cellphone valued $3,600 and $200 in cash. San Fernando detectives are investigating. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/griffith-collapses-taken-to-st-clair/article_1af4ac64-1545-51af-9408-e2b53bfb6709.html", "TITLE": " Griffith collapses; taken to St Clair ", "DATE": "Jun 4, 2013 ", "CONTENT": "STARTING THE MOMENTUM: Science and Technology Minister Dr Rupert Griffith, left, starts a pendulum in a conservation of energy display following yesterday\u0092s opening of the International Conference on Science and Technology for Economic Diversification at the Hilton Trinidad. Looking on, from right, are Planning Minister Dr Bhoe Tewarie and Central Bank Governor Jwala Rambarran. \u0097Photo: JERMAINE CRUICKSHANK STARTING THE MOMENTUM: Science and Technology Minister Dr Rupert Griffith, left, starts a pendulum in a conservation of energy display following yesterday\u0092s opening of the International Conference on Science and Technology for Economic Diversification at the Hilton Trinidad. Looking on, from right, are Planning Minister Dr Bhoe Tewarie and Central Bank Governor Jwala Rambarran. \u0097Photo: JERMAINE CRUICKSHANK Science and Technology Minister Dr Rupert Griffith was last night rushed to St Clair Medical Centre after collapsing at a cocktail reception hosted by Microsoft. Griffith, the Express was told, had been chatting with Microsoft executives around 7.30 p.m. when he suddenly lost his balance and fell backwards. He did not lose consciousness. He had earlier delivered an address at the event, held to formally open the technology companys new Trinidad base on Mucurapo Road, St James. An ambulance was immediately called and arrived about 20 minutes later to take the Toco/Sangre Grande MP to St Clair Medical, where he will undergo medical tests to determine the cause of his condition. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/sports/local/clean-russian-athetes-turn-to-rocket-science/article_43c619f0-265e-5cc2-bdb0-0772ba73d3ee.html", "TITLE": " Clean Russian athetes turn to Rocket Science ", "DATE": "Feb 26, 2017 ", "CONTENT": "Pioneers: Runner Vasily Permitin, left, and Evgeny Pishchalov, part of the Rocket Science Project, attend an interview with the Associated Press at the Russian Indoor Championships in Moscow, Russia. \u2014Photo: AP Pioneers: Runner Vasily Permitin, left, and Evgeny Pishchalov, part of the Rocket Science Project, attend an interview with the Associated Press at the Russian Indoor Championships in Moscow, Russia. \u2014Photo: AP A group of Russian track and field athletes want to beat dopers with science and show that their country can win clean. Formed in the shadow of Russia's doping scandals, the Rocket Science Project is hoping to encourage whistleblowers and create an independent training camp with a strict no-drugs policy. The group says ignorance and greed have driven Russian athletes to use drugs for years as a shortcut to success, justifying it with the belief everyone else does it too. \u201cIt's stupid to deny that we have big problems with doping in our country. As a consequence of that, sports technology, science and knowledge are probably 20 years behind the modern world level,\u201d says Evgeny Pishchalov, the slightly built distance runner-turned-coach who leads the project. \u201cIf our system doesn't restructure, we're at risk of ending up without any Olympic medals in the coming years. We've been left with no choice \u2014 change or die.\u201d Rocket Science has already launched a hotline for doping whistleblowers, and is working to set up the training camp. Members will have to pay a US$25,000 fine if they ever test positive. The group wants to stay independent of Russian institutions and sports officials accused of overseeing widespread doping. Sergei Litvinov, a top hammer thrower, says Rocket Science will accept limited cooperation but \u201cas soon as we feel any kind of pressure, we'd rather shut it all down.\u201d Russia's ban from international track and field in 2015 for widespread drug use sparked anger from Russian athletes who felt the sanction wasn't fair. As denials dominated social media debates among Russian athletes and coaches, a minority argued for reforms and a doping crackdown, and said Russia shouldn't be proud of drug cheats' medals. That sowed the seeds for the Rocket Science Project, though convincing more Russian athletes to follow their lead is hard. \u201cWe've got the mentality that all the others (in other countries) are gulping down banned substance and we do it a little less, so we're the good ones,\u201d says Vasily Permitin, a runner who's part of the project. \u201cAnd if you believe everyone is taking it, reporting on them is seen as bad.\u201d Jereem \u201cthe Dream\u201d Richards, in the Men\u2019s 200m dash, and the Men\u2019s 4x100m relay team both grabbed silver last evening, helping Team TTO to its biggest medal haul at a Pan American Games with two more days to go. Team TTO rower Felice Aisha Chow continues defying her age, creating history by becoming the first rower from this country to win a Pan American Games medal in the sport when she earned silver in the Women\u2019s Singles Sculls 2000m event yesterday at the Lima 2019 Games. The 2019 season has been a tough one for Jereem \u201cThe Dream\u201d Richards. Adversity, though, mak\u2026 Team TTO top swimmer Dylan Carter rebounded from disappointment with a bronze medal response in the Men\u2019s 100m backstroke Thursday night. After failing to deliver all series, the West Indies \u201cA\u201d batsmen finally came good to deny India \u201cA\u201d a series sweep as they held on to draw the final match of the three-game series at the Brian Lara Cricket Academy in Tarouba, yesterday. Joy turned to sorrow for Tyra Gittens in the 2019 Pan American Games women\u2019s heptathlon here in Lima, Peru. Poised for the podium following the first four disciplines, on Wednesday, disaster struck for the Trinidad and Tobago athlete early on Thursday. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/professor-castro-delivers-feature-address-at-uwi/article_21782e6d-eabd-59bc-80ce-9786bb413561.html", "TITLE": " Professor Castro delivers feature address at UWI ", "DATE": "Jul 15, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "CASTRO\u0092S SON: Pro Vice-Chancellor and Campus Principal of the University of the West Indies (UWI), St Augustine, Clement Sankat, right, speaks with Professor Fidel Castro Diaz-Balart, son of former Cuba president Fidel Castro, at the UWI Institute of International Relations\u0092 lecture entitled, Global challenges in science and innovation for sustainable development, at the Noor Hassanali Lecture Auditorium, St Augustine yesterday. \u0097Photo: ANISTO ALVES CASTRO\u0092S SON: Pro Vice-Chancellor and Campus Principal of the University of the West Indies (UWI), St Augustine, Clement Sankat, right, speaks with Professor Fidel Castro Diaz-Balart, son of former Cuba president Fidel Castro, at the UWI Institute of International Relations\u0092 lecture entitled, Global challenges in science and innovation for sustainable development, at the Noor Hassanali Lecture Auditorium, St Augustine yesterday. \u0097Photo: ANISTO ALVES Professor Dr Fidel Castro Diaz-Balart, son of former president of the Republic of Cuba Dr Fidel Castro, delivered the feature address at a special lecture held at the University of the West Indies, St Augustine yesterday. During the lecture, entitled Global Challenges in Science and Innovation for Sustainable Development: Remarks from a Cuban Perspective, Castro Diaz-Balart raised several issues pertaining to science and technology in the Caribbean. Oil and gas will be depleted within the next century or two, depending on the rate of extraction, Castro Diaz-Balart said, adding that the challenge to produce enough food will also become greater. This, he stated, is why science and technology is crucial. Cuba, Castro Diaz-Balart added, is an important example of scientific and technological achievement in the region, pointing out that Cuba has one of the highest medical doctor ratios in the region, with an estimated 60,000 doctors. Castro Diaz-Balart also stated that Cuba has 68 universities and 2.5 million people enrolled in schools across the country. Professor Andy Knight, director of UWI's Institute of International Relations, in his closing remarks, thanked Diaz-Balart for coming and stated that the lecture would prove useful for the 20 UWI students who are scheduled to travel to Cuba for a week. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/uwi-to-add-new-science-food-faculties/article_1bc13e88-d188-557d-a2c9-56470390f7dd.html", "TITLE": " UWI to add new science, food faculties ", "DATE": "Aug 15, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "The St Augustine Campus of the University of the West Indies (UWI) is awaiting university-level approval to introduce two new faculties for Science and Technology and Food and Agriculture, out of the existing Faculty of Science and Agriculture (FSA). \"What we are doing is looking at the rapid changes taking place around us, locally, regionally and globally, and, therefore, how do we realign our faculty in the face of this rapidly changing environment,\" said Prof Dyer Narinesingh, dean of the FSA. \"We feel science and technology is pivotal if we are going to bring about innovation in the region, and regarding food and agriculture, agriculture should be central to socio-economic development.\" Narinesingh was speaking to reporters on Monday after the opening ceremony for the regional training course on plant quarantine. He said pending approval, the faculties should come on stream from the 2012/2013 academic year. \"At the campus level, we have had support. We have been discussing this with stakeholders, and we feel this is the way to go,\" he added. Narinesingh said the university had gotten official approval for a new four-year Bachelor of Science (BSc) degree programme in agriculture, scheduled for the 2012/ 2013 academic year. \"The university wants to produce graduates with the skills and competencies to move the agricultural industry forward,\" he noted. Narinesingh also said UWI will be expanding the St Augustine campus with new teaching rooms at Carmoody Road, St Augustine, ready within the next academic year. He also said 200 acres at Orange Grove will house the new Agricultural Experimental Station. \"Students will be spending a lot of time on these farms getting experience.\" Food Production, Land and Marine Affairs Minister Vasant Bharath, speaking at the same event, had also revealed that a note had been sent to Cabinet to approve the appointment of 50 agriculture students from UWI to be placed on various ministry farms throughout the country. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/technology-looking-beyond-the-moon/article_3c67b402-e071-5084-815b-9885b06ea3fc.html", "TITLE": " Technology: Looking beyond the moon ", "DATE": "Aug 13, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "Adita died of head injuries Fully integrated Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft (left) and loading it to Thermovac Chamber (right). Adita died of head injuries Fully integrated Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft (left) and loading it to Thermovac Chamber (right). India has now a new brand ambassador. Chandrayaan-1, India's maiden lunar probe, has made an epochal research breakthrough by finding the strongest ever evidence of the presence of water on the moon. Chandrayaan-1, has in the eyes of the world, become a vibrant symbol of India's surging technological prowess and scientific acumen. As pointed out by G. Madhavan Nair, the then Chairman of the Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO), the message of Chandrayaan-1, which was hoisted into space in October 2008, is vocal and clear: as far as space is concerned, India is a developed country. Describing the detection of water on the moon as a historic event of great significance for the future of the deep space exploration programme, Nair observed \"So far no mission has confirmed the presence of water on the moon positively\". It was the Moon Mineralogy Mapper (M3), one of the five international payloads onboard the Rs.3860-million Indian moon mission which revealed that far from being dry, the moon harbours water in the form of molecules. In a way, this path-breaking discovery, arguably the most exciting in space exploration, stands. out as a splendid example of collaboration between the scientists from ISRO and NASA (National Aeronautics and Space Administration) of USA. The wealth of data made available by M3, built by Brown University and Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) for NASA, has shown that the chemistry of the moon is totally different from what was envisioned earlier. Fully integrated Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft (left) and loading it to Thermovac Chamber (right). \"Widespread water has been detected on the surface of the moon. You have to think outside of box on this. This was expected a decade ago,\" said Carle Pieters, the M3 principal investigator and a Planetary Geologist at Brown University. In the same vein, Jim Green, Director of Planetary Science Division of NASA headquarters in Washington DC observes, \"water ice on the moon has been something of a holy grail for lunar scientists for a very long time. This surprising finding has come about through the ingenuity, perseverance and international cooperation between ISRO and NASA.\" Clearly, this exciting discovery has gone to show that Chandrayaan-1 originally designed for a life span of two years despite having its mission terminated prematurely, has been a huge success since it has met all the objectives set for it. Nair drove home the point that the Indian moon orbiter has realized more than 95% of the scientific goals set for it. \"Finding presence of water or ice on the moon was one of the major scientific objectives of Chandrayaan-1,\" noted M. Annadurai, the Project Director of Chandrayaan-1. Scientific objectives apart, Chandrayaan-1 was also aimed at upgrading India's technological capability and providing challenging opportunities for bright, young scientists in the area of planetary research. \"From the launch pad and reaching its precise orbit around the moon and landing the MIP (Moon Impact Probe) on the lunar surface and gathering data, we have crossed all the milestones,\" says Nair. Moon Impact Probe integration with Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft. Chandrayaan-1 spacecraft undergoing pre-launch test. According to ISRO, the M3 payload has detected signs of water and hydroxyl on the surface soil and rocks at widely diverse zones of the sunlit regions of the moon. This has dispelled the long held view that the moon is bone dry and water on the moon is found only in craters in the shadowed polar regions. As pointed out by Nair, the presence of water on the moon could pave way for a host of activities including the setting up of observatories, human bases, launching deep space inter-planetary missions by using the moon as the base and also extracting fuel for rockets. Of course, mining of the lunar resources including Helium-3, a green and rich energy source, could be another beneficial fall out of the discovery of water on the moon. In yet another landmark finding, the SARA (Sub Kev Atom Reflecting Analyser) payload onboard Chandrayaan-1 has found that water on the moon is generated internally. SARA payload was contributed by the European Space Agency (ESA) by way of collaboration between Swedish Institute of Space Physics and Space Physics Laboratory of the Thiruvananthapuram based Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC), the largest space establishment under ISRO. The SARA data has revealed that the moon acts like a big sponge by constantly absorbing electrically charged particles spewed by the sun. Hydrogen molecules in these particles interact with the oxygen present in dust particles found on the lunar surface to produce water. PSLV-C11 Lift off Chandrayaan-1 India's first Mission to Moon. Perhaps the crowning glory of the Indian lunar probe has been the discovery of water by the Indian built 29-kg MIP payload while crashing on the lunar surface on Nov. 14, 2008 coinciding with the birthday of the first Indian Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru, who had envisioned the need for India to stay ahead in science and technology. \"The MIP while falling on the moon picked up strong signals of water particles. It was varying from the moon's equator to the poles. These variations from equator to poles coincided with the findings from M3\" states Nair. Incidentally, MIP was meant to provide ISRO an insight into the technology of robotic space landing systems. Indian built 29-kg Moon Impact Probe (MIP) One big achievement of MIP was the planting of the Indian national flag on the lunar surface. For this payload which was included in the Chandrayaan-1 mission, at the behest of the former Indian President and well known space scientist Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, featured the painting of the Indian tricolour on all its sides. And with this signal achievement India became the fourth country in the world to put a robotic probe on the moon and plant its national flag. Moments after the flawless MIP crash-landing on the surface of the moon, a joyous Nair said, \"We had promised the country that we will deliver the moon and we have done it.\" Profiling the achievement of Chandrayaan-1 during 312 days of its mission life, ISRO says that it has completed around 3,400 orbits and made available more than 70,000 high quality images, some of which provide a breathtaking view of the lunar mountains and craters in the permanently shadowed regions of the moon. Incidentally, this challenging and complex mission to the moon, was taken up by ISRO with a view to strengthen India's position as a forward looking space power keen on exploring the deeper reaches of outer space with a greater vigour in the years ahead. The flawless launch of Chandrayaan-1 on October 22, 2008 by means of the four stage reliable Indian space workhorse PSLV (Polar Satellite Launch Vehicle) and its subsequent insertion into the lunar orbit has catapulted India into the elite group of countries USA, Russia, China, Japan and ESA which have launched probes to earth's nearest celestial neighbour. Indeed, for a developing nation that began its space journey in a modest way back in 1963 with the test firing of a 9-kg. sounding rocket from the fishing hamlet of Thumba on the outskirts of Thiruvananthapuram, Chandrayaan-1 marks a giant leap ahead. Moreover, Chandrayaan-1 is known to have cost only a fraction of the investment on similar probes launched by other space faring nations including China and Japan. \"With a miniscule budget, we have mastered cutting edge space technology\" quipped Nair. The discovery of water on the moon by Chandrayaan-I has opened up the exciting possibility of reorienting the mission goals of the follow on lunar probe Chandrayaan-II slated for launch during 2012-2013 by means of the three stage Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle (GSLV). In this context Dr. Kalam has suggested ISRO go deeper into the lunar crust for water by employing the robotic penetrator. \"This discovery of water is all the more important because this comes after five decades of space research efforts by many nations. I suggest ISRO and NASA work on Chandrayaan-II to help explore the depths at which water is available by drilling holes on the lunar surface, using a moon surface robotic penetrator.\" Chandrayaan-II will be a Indo-Russian project. While ISRO will be responsible for the main orbiter, Russia will develop the main robotic rover with a landing system. Along with the originally planned 50-kg Russian rover, Chandayaan-II will now be reconfigured to include a 15-kg Indian built rover. Both these rovers which will make a soft landing on a lunar site to be identified using data from Chandrayaan-I will collect soil and rock samples and subject them to chemical analysis to look for further evidence for water and Helium-3. \"We are making a mid course correction for Chandrayaan-II. We will mine the moon's surface much deeper to fi nd more water,\" remarks Nair. Beyond Chandrayaan-II, ISRO is looking at the possibility of going in for a sample return mission to the moon. For this mission, ISRO would need a heavy lift off rocket. The semi cryogenic rocket propulsion system being developed by ISRO could help meet the thrust required for the sample return mission. ISRO has also hinted at the possibility of mining the lunar resources. \"If we find minerals on the moon, the next logical step would be to collect them and get them back to earth\" says Nair. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/unfair-allocation-of-open-scholarships-by-govt/article_2c832076-a399-5a2f-9e43-0753bbb1f230.html", "TITLE": " Unfair allocation of open scholarships by Govt ", "DATE": "Sep 3, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "This is in reference to an article which appeared in Friday's Express, \"324 to get schols\". The breakdown of the number of open scholarships was listed as technological studies and visual and performing arts with two each; business, environmental studies, language arts and modern studies with three each; mathematics with nine and sciences with 29. While I congratulate the government for increasing the number of scholarships that will be awarded this year, why is it that science and math have the most scholarships whereas every other area has significantly less As a modern studies and language student, I find it insulting and unfair that the sciences, or as some like to call them, the \"harder subjects\", are given preference over the other fields. Yes, it might be argued that more people study the sciences, but 29 and three is much too large a gap. And if it is that the math and science students perform better in exams than students from other areas, shouldn't something be done to change this Maybe the Ministry of Education needs to provide more training for these teachers, or improve the methods by which these subjects are taught in schools. Or, maybe these other subjects are in fact the \"harder\" ones, contrary to popular belief. From my own personal experience, both within and outside of school, I have realised that the sciences are continuously placed on a pedestal while business or language students, for example, are forced to sit on the sidelines and face ridicule and scorn because they are \"dumb\", or their subjects are \"so much easier\". On reading this article, I was extremely disappointed to find that our own Ministry of Education is engaging in this behaviour as well, and is, in fact, contributing to the under-appreciation of any student who does not study the sciences. There must be some logic or explanation behind the allocation of scholarships, but maybe I am not \"smart enough\" to figure it out. Shouldn't every student, no matter what one studies, be given an equal opportunity at earning a scholarship This very uneven distribution of scholarships is both disheartening and upsetting to the students who do not study science or math. I challenge the ministry to fix this glaring problem by next year, and show appreciation for students of every field. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/suruj-suggests-computer-code-of-practice/article_1c91b49e-3fd1-50c4-8516-cf50af104528.html", "TITLE": " Suruj suggests computer code of practice ", "DATE": "Apr 28, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "WORKS Minister Dr Suruj Rambachan has suggested the establishment of codes of practice regarding the use of computers and technology, so that society's value systems are not destroyed. Speaking following Monday's launch of the National Science Centre's Community Science Week at Gasparillo Composite School, Rambachan told reporters: \"I do not know whether it (technology) is negative or positive. That technology is there and what has to be done (is) introduce in the minds of people right use of the technology.\" He said that the issue had to be examined, not just with the growing use of Facebook, but with computers generally. The issue of the use of social media became a national discussion last week, when a Facebook video, showing a woman beating her 12-year-old child with a belt after the child posted indecent photographs, was posted and went viral. Rambachan said codes of practice \"might have to be developed for the use of computers and technology that is not inimical to progress, but at the same time it does not destroy the value systems in society\". Rambachan said the nation had to \"behave like a developed country\" so that people will not be \"short changing\" themselves. NIHERST's Community Science Week will feature a series of activities, including exhibitions, presentations and workshops. The aim of NIHERST is to expose science and technology to the rural and under-served communities by tailoring for those needs. The science week hosted by NIHERST will end May 3. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/online_features/education/how-new-technologies-will-support-steam-learning-this-school-year/article_25f04e19-aa06-5ead-a450-7c05a902b762.html", "TITLE": " How New Technologies Will Support STEAM Learning this School Year ", "DATE": "Sep 1, 2018 ", "CONTENT": "(StatePoint) With each new school year comes a brand-new set of subjects, books and teachers. It also means new technologies being introduced into the classroom. As students head back to school, here is a look at the technologies that will support STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and math) learning this year. \u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Digital Art: Enter some art classes today and you may find a dearth of paints, brushes and charcoal. Today, art students can learn the same painting, drawing and sculpting techniques they previously would have learned using traditional supplies, only with digital tools instead. While the traditional mediums aren\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t completely going away any time soon, today\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s students can benefit from the versatility that cutting-edge tools supply, from the time a project idea is conceived through when the finished product is shared with the world. \u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Visual Science: Whether it\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s an anatomical diagram of the human heart or a map of the Milky Way, every science teacher knows that a picture\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s worth a thousand words, particularly when it\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s a sharp, clear picture. Teachers and students are benefitting from top of the line projection technology in classrooms. The LampFree Projectors from Casio\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s Core Series, for example, have the ability to project images and video wirelessly from smart phones, laptop computers and tablets, expanding teachers\u00e2\u20ac\u2122 ability to create engaging lesson plans. Additionally, the mercury-free Laser and LED hybrid light source is energy-efficient, reducing power consumption by up to 40 percent, a bonus lesson in environmental stewardship. \u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Accessible Computer Science: Certain innovations are helping students go beyond just consuming technology. Apps abound for independent learners, as well as educators, to use in their classrooms to help computer science students of all ages and abilities to hone their coding skills. From straight-forward instructional apps to those that gamify the learning process, young coders-in-training have a wealth of resources at their fingertips. \u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Intuitive Music: New technology is rocking the music education boat in an effort to make learning an instrument more intuitive. For example, Casio\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s LK-265 is outfitted with such tools as a Key Lighting System, Voice Fingering Guide and Step-up Lesson System, enabling beginners to learn built-in songs at their own pace. Additionally, an LCD display makes mastering music notation and correct hand positioning easy. Students don\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t even have to wait for teacher feedback -- the keyboards have a Scoring System that evaluates performance. \u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 In-Depth Math: Today\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s students are getting a closer look at the inner workings of mathematics than their predecessors, thanks to new graphing calculators, such as the fx-CG50 PRIZM and fx-CG500, which offer expanded features, including the ability to easily draw three dimensional graphs such as planes, cylinders and spheres, and view them from various angles to better analyze their shapes. A cross-section option and special zoom function allow students to closely examine graphs for in-depth analysis and an improved catalog function means students can use commands more easily and quickly. As rapidly emerging technologies innovate education, it\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s an exciting time to be a student or teacher. ***** Photo Credit: (c) Monkey Business/stock.Adobe.com TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. Looking on from right are Jwala Rambaran, NIHERST chairman, Janelle Daniel and a pupil of Guaico Government Secondary School. \u0097Photo: ISHMAEL SALANDY BRAINTEASER: Tertiary Education Minister Fazal Karim, left, uses a game called 'Mind flex' during yesterday's opening of SciTecknoFest 2011 at the National Science Centre, in D'Abadie. Speaking after the launch of SciTecknoFest at the National Science Centre, D'Abadie yesterday, Minister of Science, Technology and Tertiary Education Fazal Karim said: \"We are now in the process of developing these plans in conjunction with the Ministry of Health as we recognise there is a shortage of nurses in this country.\" Karim said he will be taking a note to Cabinet and hoped that it is approved shortly because he had talked with Minister of Sport Anil Roberts about using the El Dorado Girls Youth Camp as a centre. \"That facility, once we obtain it, will be utilised by College of Science, Technology and Applied Arts of Trinidad and Tobago (COSTAATT) and by the University of the West Indies in conjunction with the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Science, Technology and Tertiary Education to increase not only nurses but the entire medical profession.\" He said the OJT programme has been repositioned to the National Training Academy (NTA) like the Life Skills programme and there are also hopes that more young people will soon be able to work at the National Science Centre which he plans to acquire lands to expand. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/us-embassy-announces-delegates-to-national-youth-science-camp/article_c96f1811-d4fc-5238-a32f-963e03f3c08c.html", "TITLE": " US Embassy announces Delegates to 2014 National Youth Science Camp ", "DATE": "Jun 25, 2014 ", "CONTENT": "Left to right U.S. Embassy Charge d\u0092Affaires Margaret Diop, NYSC participants Lisa Thomas and Alyssa Mike and NIHERST President Maureen Manchouck. Photo courtesyof the U.S. Embassy. Left to right U.S. Embassy Charge d\u0092Affaires Margaret Diop, NYSC participants Lisa Thomas and Alyssa Mike and NIHERST President Maureen Manchouck. Photo courtesyof the U.S. Embassy. The U.S. Embassy is pleased to announce the selection of two outstanding students from Trinidad and Tobago Alyssa Mike and Lisa Thomas as delegates to the National Youth Science Camp in West Virginia, USA. Selections were made in coordination with the National Institute for Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology (NIHERST). The U.S. Embassy, in coordination with NIHERST, identified these two participants as among the most promising young scientific leaders in Trinidad. Both delegates showed strong academic achievement in science and potential for thoughtful scientific leadership. Alyssa Mike of St. Josephs Convent San Fernando presented strong credentials in Applied Mathematics, Biology, Chemistry, Caribbean Studies and Pure Mathematics. She hopes to pursue her studies in medicine and biomedical engineering. Lisa Thomas of Naparima Girls High School, San Fernando presented strong credentials in Biology, Chemistry, Physics and Caribbean Studies. Lisa is very passionate about science, especially in the field of medical research and hopes to be instrumental in finding cures for HIV and Cancer. At the invitation of Governor Earl Ray Tomblin of West Virginia, Alyssa Mike and Lisa Thomas will participate as delegates in the 51st year of the National Youth Science Camp. The camp will be held near the National Radio Astronomy Observatory at Green Bank, West Virginia. The National Youth Science Camp was established in 1963 as a part of West Virginias Centennial Celebration. The National Youth Science Camp is an annual summer forum where two delegates representing each state exchange ideas with leading scientists and other professionals from academic and corporate worlds. Scientists present lectures and hands-on research, covering some of the most provocative topics in science today topics such as fractal geometry, the human genome project, global climate change, the history of the universe, the fate of our rain forests, and robotics. Delegates to the Science Camp are challenged to explore new areas in biological and physical sciences, art, and music with resident staff members. The Science Camp would not only offer the delegates cutting edge information from leading scientists, but also allow them to build lasting friendships with other participants who shared their interests and talents. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/conscience-con-science/article_ca070ae6-7f0f-577f-b965-19210045e606.html", "TITLE": " Conscience con science ", "DATE": "Apr 20, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Tatil employees attend the special cake cutting ceremony that was held in honour of Tatil\u0092s 50th Anniversary. Tatil employees attend the special cake cutting ceremony that was held in honour of Tatil\u0092s 50th Anniversary. I am pretty sure that PNM leader Keith Rowley never told his fellow MPs they could vote according to their conscience, for why would he use words they don't understand He might as well have spoken Latin, which is the dead language that 99 per cent of the PNM's supporters don't know their motto is written in. Tell them that \"Magnum est PNM et prevalebit\" and they'll either ask you for ice cream, tell you champagne tickles their nose, or pull out a 357. and shoot you for cussing their mother. Last Saturday, the PNM General Council met to discuss the split on the Opposition bench which occurred in the Lower House on Friday when former PNM leader Patrick Manning moved a motion for his lawyers to argue for him before the Privileges Committee. According to the party's PR officer Faris Al-Rawi, \"We are holding on to the fact that it was a simple miscommunication.\" But that's what happens when politicians start using words like conscience, principle or floccinaucinihilipilification. The confusion in Parliament last Friday apparently started with Port of Spain North MP Patricia McIntosh, a former school principal who, Al-Rawi might be surprised to know, actually has qualifications in communication. As Manning was presenting his motion, McIntosh told Dr Rowley that, contrary to a decision taken in caucus, she wanted to support Manning. \"I liked his rationale and my conscience would not allow me to abstain or vote against the motion,\" McIntosh explained later, according to media reports. \"This is how I live my life, on principle and conscience.\" I suspect, though, that journalists misunderstood McIntosh's pronunciation. As the former head of St Francois Girls' College, McIntosh may have said that she lives her life as principal, not principle, which is why she views the PNM caucus as a group of unruly children who need to be taught how to read, write, and not have sex until they're married. And she probably said she lives her life, not on conscience, but unconscious. That would explain why she's totally unaware that Manning didn't present a shred of evidence to support his allegations that Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar had built her private home without proper approvals and using money from suspect sources. It also explains why McIntosh apparently forgot that, in an interview with the Trinidad Guardian in June last year, she said, \"It's now time for a new leader,\" and \"We have to support (Dr Rowley) in our effort to rebuild the PNM and to have proper representation.\" So don't expect McIntosh's conscience to instruct her to resign now that she has supported the old leader, didn't support Rowley, didn't give proper representation in Parliament, and helped undermine the PNM. The Oxford English Dictionary defines \"conscience\" as \"a person's moral sense of right and wrong\" and, since this is a woman who revealed that she ran as a candidate in the 2010 general election after God said she should, her conscience probably tells her whatever she wants to hear. Naturally then, since Manning always says He always obeys god, McIntosh would naturally obey Him and him (and, no, I didn't make a mistake in capitalising my pronouns). McIntosh even changed her story later, saying that when she broached her feelings with Rowley, he told her \"Do what you want\" which, having a degree in Modern Languages, she interpreted as permission to have a conscience vote. (She also has a Diploma in Mass Communication, yet never learned to recognise sarcasm.) With her certificate in Communication Technology, McIntosh then felt compelled to tell her fellow MPs that Rowley had said they could vote how they want. La Brea MP Fitzgerald Jeffrey happily swallowed this, but later said that his support \"goes only behind Dr Keith Rowley\" that preposition perhaps more Freudian than Jeffrey realised. Diego Martin Central MP Amery Browne also voted in favour of Manning's motion, saying he did so for \"principle and conscience\", hence proving my contention about PNM-ites getting confused by unfamiliar words. By Browne's definition, he must have viewed Calder Hart's salary as conscience money; and he must have remained quiet in good conscience when Manning's prophetess started constructing a $30 million church behind God's back; and he must have been a conscientious objector when he thumped his Parliament desk in October 2008 as Manning falsely alleged that $10 million had vanished on Rowley's watch as Housing Minister. But the two PNM-ites who most represented our politicians were Arouca/Maloney MP Alicia Hospedales and St Ann's MP Joanne Thomas. Hospedales actually seconded Manning's motion, then ducked out of the Chamber so she wouldn't have to vote on it, hence demonstrating the overriding political principle to say one thing and do another. Thomas told reporters that she didn't avoid the vote but had to go to the bathroom at just that moment: and that explanation is also typical of our nation's politicians, since it sounds like a load of crap. kbaldeosingh@hotmail.com TWO videos which show minors engaged in sexual acts with adults are now engaging the attenti\u2026 The prisoner who escaped from the Maximum Security Prison on Thursday, has been found. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/trade-minister-science-park-is-a-go/article_36667b89-63d6-5121-b751-ca115e227bc4.html", "TITLE": " Trade Minister: Science park 'is a go' ", "DATE": "Jun 30, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "The multi-million-dollar Tamana In tech Park, which is currently being built at Wallerfield, is not one of the mega-projects that will be shelved under the new People's Partnership Government. Speaking to reporters after a Rotary Club of Port of Spain luncheon on Tuesday, Minister of Trade Stephen Cadiz said, \"Tamana will continue, Tamana is a go. We have some work to do; however, the original concept is still there. A lot of work was done on putting the infrastructure in at Tamana.\" The Rotary Club meeting was held at Goodwill Industries at Fitzblackman Drive, Port of Spain. He said the focus of the special purpose company which oversees the Tamana Park, ETecK, is now on finding tenants for the science park. On the hustings, Cadiz's boss, Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar, said under a People's Partnership Government the focus for development would not be on mass industrialisation and mega-projects. After her first Cabinet meeting on June 1, she also told the media, many of the country's larger projects need to be reviewed before her Ministers could say which would be continued and which would be stopped. She assured the public not all mega-projects started under the former People's National Movement Government would be shut down. Tamana is one of the first mega-projects to get the thumbs up. The park will be the only science and information technology park in the West Indies and will also house the headquarters of the University of Trinidad and Tobago. In the days before the May 24 election, ETecK's communications manager Carol-Ann McKenzie, said that 60 per cent of the park would be done when ETecK has a soft launch in September. Cadiz did not speak to the likelihood of a September opening, saying only that there was still a lot of work to be done. Another Ministry of Trade multi-million-dollar project which Cadiz will continue is the development of a Single Electronic Window (SEW), the first phase of which is to be done by the end of 2010. Sources at the Ministry of Trade said the first phase of the information technology upgrade would cost $90 million to roll out. The SEW is an IT-based facilitation tool which will allow parties involved in trade and transport to lodge standardised information and documents at a single entry point, in order to fulfil all import, export, and transit- related regulatory requirements online. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/guardian-life-and-uwi-host-teaching-awards/article_e9901c12-7390-57ba-a3b4-6a6ffa87a624.html", "TITLE": " Guardian Life and UWI host teaching awards ", "DATE": "Aug 31, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "For the sixth time, Guardian Life will collaborate with the University of the West Indies to host its bi-annual Premium Teaching Awards, a ceremony that recognises and celebrates the excellent teaching that classifies the St Augustine Campus. This year marks the 12th year of this partnership between Guardian Life and UWI which began in 1998. The Premium Teaching Awards are alternated every other year with the Premium Open Lecture Series on learning and teaching in higher education. This year's ceremony is set to take place on October 1 at 5 p.m. at Daaga Auditorium, UWI. The theme for this year's Awards is \"Teaching Excellence and Social Media\" and Dr Brian Croxall, Council on Library and Information Resources (CLIR) Postdoctoral Fellow and Emerging Technologies Librarian, Woodruff Library, Emory University, will be featured as the key speaker. Four nominees have submitted portfolios to the judges. They are Dr Wayne Goodrigde, Faculty of Science and Agriculture; Dr Shivananda Nayak, Faculty of Medical Sciences; Dr Grace Sirju-Charran, Faculty of Science and Agriculture; and Dr Charlene Roach, Faculty of Social Sciences. This event is free and invitations are extended to UWI staff, students and alumni, principals of secondary schools and tertiary level institutions. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/utt-maritime-studies-to-host-the-maritime-technology-cooperation-centre/article_32328984-613b-5c21-b33f-91fa9beb6494.html", "TITLE": " UTT Maritime Studies to host The Maritime Technology Cooperation Centre (MTCC) for the Caribbean Region ", "DATE": "Jan 11, 2017 ", "CONTENT": "UTT Chaguaramas Campus \u2013 MTCC for the Caribbean Region. Photo Sarita Emmanuel UTT Chaguaramas Campus \u2013 MTCC for the Caribbean Region. Photo Sarita Emmanuel The University of Trinidad and Tobago (UTT) has been selected by the International Maritime Organization (IMO) to host the regional Maritime Technology Cooperation Centre (MTCC) for the Caribbean. The IMO also announced that under the Global MTCC Network (GMN) project, Shanghai Maritime University in China will host MTCC-Asia and a further three (3) MTCCs will be established in other target regions - Africa, Latin America and the Pacific. These MTCCs will form a global network which will work towards promoting ship energy-efficiency technologies and operations, and the reduction of harmful emissions from ships. This project, which is implemented by the IMO, is funded by the European Union (EU). In its role as the MTCC-Caribbean, UTT will: \u2022 Provide a platform for partnerships aimed at reducing emissions and enhancing energy efficient methods in the Maritime domain at a global level and specifically in the Caribbean region \u2022 Identify environmentally friendly and sustainable technologies available to the Caribbean region \u2022 Enhance awareness and uptake of environmentally sound technologies and build expertise within the region \u2022 Provide advisory and market development services for technology adopters and suppliers \u2022 Monitor regional energy efficiency needs and align training programmes to meet these needs. Over a three year period, the five regional MTCCs will deliver mutually-agreed project milestones while contributing toward the IMO's continuing, efforts to ensure effective implementation and enforcement of the global energy-efficiency regulations for international shipping. UTT's selection comes on the heels of a competitive tendering process which is a testament to the quality of the maritime agenda undertaken by the University as well as its focus on capacity-building in this important sector. Through specific academic and professional programmes which are geared toward meeting the human resource demands of the maritime industry, UTT continues to develop both the seafaring and shore-based competencies necessary for driving this highly specialised area. The University's academic programmes have received international accreditation with the Institute of Marine Engineering Science and Technology (IMarEST) while its seafaring programmes are accredited by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency (MCA) of the United Kingdom and the Maritime Services Division of the Ministry of Works and Transport. As host of the MTCC-Caribbean, UTT will continue to make an indelible impact on the local, regional and international maritime sectors. The University looks forward to the many contributions which can be enacted through this designation and will carry-on its efforts to build capacity in the international maritime industry. The MTCC team constitutes Mrs. Vivian Rambarath-Parasram (Project Director and Head), Captain Sukhjit Singh (Deputy Head and Technical Lead), Mr. Isikeli Waqa (Energy Efficiency Advisor), Mr. Stephan Nanan (Green House Gas Advisor) and Mrs. Sarita Mahabir-Lee (Communications and Visibility Lead).
