{"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/maureen-manchouck-honoured/article_077c6f9b-2577-5cf5-9244-84f1876aae56.html", "TITLE": " Maureen Manchouck honoured ", "DATE": "Oct 31, 2012 ", "CONTENT": "DREAM COME TRUE: Maureen Manchouck, left, receives her honorary LLD from Sir George Alleyne, Chancellor of the University of the West Indies, during its graduation ceremonies held recently at UWI, St Augustine. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE DREAM COME TRUE: Maureen Manchouck, left, receives her honorary LLD from Sir George Alleyne, Chancellor of the University of the West Indies, during its graduation ceremonies held recently at UWI, St Augustine. \u0097Photo: CURTIS CHASE The UWI St Augustine Campus conferred an honorary LLD on Maureen Manchouck, during its graduation ceremonies in October 2012. Manchouck discussed her ideas on science education with UWI Today. The following is an excerpt of that interview. You have been a strong advocate for popularising science education through a number of innovative programmes; if you had the resources what else would you do For the last 20 years, my big, unfulfilled dream for science popularisation has been to see the building of a world-class, purpose-built national science centre. This should be the physical backbone or platform for all the programmes we offer: a fitting house to invite our people into and make them feel more at home with science and technologyan environment that inspires and showcases the very best of science and scientistslocal, regional and international. And I am pleased to say that it seems that this dream will finally come true. In March of this year, Cabinet approved a 52-acre plot of land in Couva for the construction of a new national science centre. This centre is envisaged as a complex of facilities (viz. a science city) and will be built in phases. The building itself will be constructed as a giant exhibit and will serve as an exemplar of environmentally sustainable practice in building design. The facilities will include, in addition to the permanent exhibit galleries, an innovation centre built for 14-24 year olds; a green outdoor space for relaxation and educational entertainment with experiments, an amphitheatre, etc. for use by the public; open-ended, safe 'learn-through-play' science experiences and programmes geared to young children from toddlers to eight-year-olds; an Ideas Gallery dedicated to blurring the boundaries between science and the arts and exploring the roles and relevance of new technologies, and scientific laboratories. The Caribbean should have had a network of science centres by now, as was recommended in an IDB report almost 20 years ago by consultant, Prof Errol Miller. Twenty years ago, despite the fact that all around the world developing countries were recognising the important role of science centres, science popularisation here in Trinidad and Tobago was seen, at best, as the soft side of building scientific capability and, at worst, a luxury for only wealthy countries to invest in. NIHERST still managed to create the only science centre in this region. South Africa started off at the same time as we did with science popularisation and now has at least 25 science centres. The same goes for India. It established the NCSM in 1978 and that is today the largest network of science centres/museums under a single administrative umbrella in the world, with 27 facilities across the country and more on the horizon. And now, not coincidentally I think, these are two of the emerging BRICS countries. The establishment of science centresvital education avenues in themselveswas reflective of a wider policy, which was being adopted in those countries, of embracing and investing in science education and scientific research. They are reaping the fruits of those policies today. In terms of science education, how do you feel the secondary school curriculum can be refined Refinement of the curriculum in science education at the secondary level cannot be taken to mean tinkering primarily with subject matter/content, as important as this is, but it must also occur at the system level. Meaningful curriculum refinement in science, and in many other subject areas, must arise from the understanding that all students can benefit from relevant and appropriate science education experiences. But what is taught should not just be for the purpose of passing an examination. Nor should science subjects be options to drop halfway through secondary school if the student will not be pursuing them at higher levels. Science should be mandatory up to fifth form as are Mathematics, English and Spanish. Every student should be leaving secondary school with a basic solid understanding of science that would be of some value to them later in their lives. This will be a stronger base for shaping a more scientifically literate society to fuel growth and innovation. The secondary school curriculum is still largely a one-size-fits-all entity. What is clearly needed here is a science curriculum at the secondary level with explicit learning outcomes for all students, including the very able as well as those who are not likely to go to tertiary education. The learning outcomes can be made compatible with CXC requirements as well as providing clear achievement challenges for a range of learners who may not be either interested in or capable of achieving the learning outcomes at CXC level. An important aspect of this approach is the need for the secondary system to establish clearly what secondary school graduation in this country means. The unsatisfactory performance in science at the secondary level can be attributed to weak teaching as good and experienced science teachers are not to be found in large numbers throughout the school system. The importance of teacher education at UWI and in other tertiary institutions cannot be overstated. It is now widely understood that tertiary education accreditation and quality assurance are key reform elements in this area. A growing sense of professionalism in science education is an important prerequisite. I also believe that in science education, as in many other curricular areas, a major refinement would be to put the curriculum on a credit basis including minimum credit requirements in science education and mathematics, which all students are required to meet. Of course, a number of students will exceed these requirements but we are concerned here with the education system being better able to enable all students to achieve their full potential and, in the process, provide the right type of output required for business, industry and responsible citizenship in a global context. Additionally, students of all subjects but especially science should work on projects and in teams to better prepare them for the world of work generally and of scientific research or innovative activity especially. There is increasing understanding of these new imperatives as evidenced by the growing interest in the development of a seamless system of education and training from the preschool to the tertiary level, informed by a long-term perspective on the whole teaching/learning process, and characterised by fresh and innovative approaches to teaching, learning and curriculum development at all levels of the system. There is an urgent need for us to wean ourselves from rote learning in curriculum design and instruction. This reform cannot be confined to the secondary level and has to be complemented by reform throughout the system and, in particular, at the elementary and preschool levels. From the earliest ages, students need to learn to work in ways that will better prepare them for real life situations, especially as scientists. These are basic skills for future scientists: working on projects and in teams; exploring solutions to problems in the community; the application of abstract concepts; as well as design and engineering principles. It is clear to most educators globally that in science education there is a need to move beyond the traditional approach. I believe that considerably more resources need to be devoted to fine-tuning the science curriculum, conceptualised and operationalised in seamless system terms. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/mapping-oceans-from-trinidad-to-estonia/article_38b76dcb-76ca-5785-b8ce-59d48ecac040.html", "TITLE": " Mapping Oceans From Trinidad to Estonia* ", "DATE": "Jan 5, 2018 ", "CONTENT": " DR NICOLE Delpeche-Ellmann is a trailblazer in science. She's the first Trinidadian marine scientist to work at the Tallinn University of Technology in the Eastern European country of Estonia and is among the few Caribbean scientists who live and work in Europe. Her career puts her in a unique and challenging position; globally, women make up less than 30 per cent of the workforce in the field of science. Although she may not be the first to admit it, Delpeche-Ellmann, who is both private and unassuming, is unwittingly paving the way for up-and-coming generations of female scientists. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/developing-the-agriculture-sector/article_fd2d99b4-f767-50da-84e0-74cd61df2d10.html", "TITLE": " Developing the agriculture sector ", "DATE": "Sep 14, 2010 ", "CONTENT": "WORSE FOR THE CHILDREN: Diana Mahabir-Wyatt WORSE FOR THE CHILDREN: Diana Mahabir-Wyatt Part V In my last article I gave the management of our heavy clay soils as an example of an area in which there is the need for research to support our agriculture sector. There are many other areas in which research is urgently needed. In 2004 a report on \"Strategic Intervention\" for the Ministry of Agriculture, Land and Marine Resources (MALMR) was prepared in collaboration with UWI. The Strategic Intervention report (at one time available on the ministry website) stated: \"There is limited opportunity for upward mobility of (research) staff. The terms and conditions of service, training needs, conditions of work, recognition, rewards and sanctions are not adequately addressed. The remuneration structure of the ministry is unable to attract researchers of high calibre. Research staff is often engaged in non-research/administrative/diagnostic (testing) activities. \"With respect to extension, a major concern is the limited transfer (of information) between the research and extension divisions. From the perspective of getting technology information, farmers hold extension officers in low esteem compared to agricultural specialists in the agribusiness enterprises. \"Extension officers are used for administrative services eg. financial, personnel, and compliance. Not enough time and focus are given for technology transfer. Extension officers are not equipped with up-to-date communication and diagnostic tools for field work in the support of the problems of farmers. \" There are limited opportunities for the upgrading of technological skills for extension officers. The rewards, recognition and promotion system does not recognise performance and officers appear to have no leadership and direction.\" The Strategic Intervention report further proposed that there should eventually be a National Agricultural Research and Extension Institute, independent of the ministry. The above indicates that up to 2004 opinion within the ministry was in support of separating the research and extension activities into an independent institution. Such a stand-alone institution does not have the advantages that can be derived from being part of a university as it does not include the staff and students of a teaching institution as described in my article in the Express of September 2 for the US Colleges of Agriculture which combine teaching, research and extension. This was recommended to the University of Trinidad and Tobago (UTT) by a committee which I chaired in 2006. I shall describe the present status of implementation of the recommendations of that committee as far as one can understand the situation from publicly available sources. The first deviation from the recommendations of the committee is that the research and extension activities of the ministry responsible for agriculture have not yet been integrated into UTT and there seems to be reluctance on the part of the ministry to carry forward this process. It would be tragic if the resistance of a few were to delay progress in developing a strong support system for a vibrant agricultural sector. The second deviation from the original recommendations is the agricultural degree programmes being offered by UTT. Whereas the recommendation was for a single degree programme in Agricultural Technology particularly aimed at preparing farm-ready graduates who could become \"new\" farmers with tertiary level training, UTT is offering five degrees in the field of agriculture but specialised in separate programmes for crops or livestock. Three of these are to be \"science\" degrees: Bachelor of Science in (1) Crop Science and Technology, (2) Animal Science and Technology and (3) Biotechnology with options in plants or animals. The other two are \"technology\" degrees: Bachelor of Technology in (1) Animal Science and Technology and (2) Crop Science and Technology. Details are available on the UTT website. Note that there is no degree offering agriculture as the production of both crops and livestock as would be the case in many farms in this country. The committee emphasised that there should be no duplication with the UWI which offers a science-based degree in agriculture as opposed to a technology-based programme. A biotechnology degree programme should be at post-graduate level as in most universities since the subject is so broad that it is better to go into a specialised area of biotechnology after taking an undergraduate degree in genetics and biochemistry. The number of graduates in biotechnology required for the foreseeable future does not justify an undergraduate programme but rather a programme with a smaller number of graduates. Regrettably \"biotechnology\" is now a buzz word which impresses the lay persons making the decisions\"genetic engineering\"and all thatso it is likely to find support at the expense of producing farmers who are well trained as entrepreneurs to develop the agricultural industry! Another programme recommended by the committee and being offered by UTT is in food technology. However, this should be reconsidered since UWI also offers a programme in food technology. To mount six new degrees, in addition to a number of existing diploma programmes, will require a wide range of scientific staff. Further, if the integration of the research division of the ministry into UTT is being delayed or abandoned this will mean much duplication of staff between the ministry and UTT. I fear that the possibility of developing a vibrant agriculture sector will be greatly reduced if the concept of integrating teaching, research and extension is abandoned. {"SOURCE": "https://www.trinidadexpress.com/news/local/george-govt-looking-to-india-to-develop-broadband-access/article_81f2f2e1-d346-5b7b-b33c-236832c74457.html", "TITLE": " George: Govt looking to India to develop broadband access ", "DATE": "Dec 21, 2011 ", "CONTENT": "Government is looking to India for their expertise in broadband Internet access and water management technologies, says Public Utilities Minister Emmanuel George. George will be one of the ministers on the 60-member delegation travelling to India in January with Prime Minister Kamla Persad-Bissessar. Speaking to the Express yesterday, George said he will be going with the aim of exploring India's use of technology in the area of broadband. He pointed out that the People's Partnership's manifesto promised to ensure that this country is developed in terms of technology. A nationwide broadband service where every person can have a connection to the Internet is a step in that direction, George said. George said he will also be holding discussions with respect to water and improved delivery to the people. He said the supply of water to people continues to be one of the ministry's biggest challenges, but he was committed to ensuring water for all. Persad-Bissessar has been invited by the Indian Government for a state visit where she will also be the chief guest at the annual Pravasi Bhartiya Divas event in Jaipur, which recognises non-resident Indians (NRIs) globally. A team of over 60 persons will be heading to India on this mission where a number of bilateral meetings will also be held. Also on the trip to India are representatives from the University of the West Indies (UWI); University of Trinidad and Tobago (UTT); National Institute of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology (NIHERST); Youth Training and Employment Partnership Programme (YTEPP); and the Ministry of Science, Technology and Tertiary Education. UWI Principal Prof Clement Sankat and his wife will be heading to India where a number of memoranda of understanding (MOU) will be signed with various institutions there, including the Punjab Agricultural College, Punjab Technical University, Jawaharlal Nehru University, Energy and Resource Institute, National University of Education Planning and Administration (NUEPA), Shri Amit Khare International Co-operation cell, All Institute of Medical Sciences, Indira Gandhi National Open University, All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Indian Council of Agricultural Research, Delhi University, Film and Television Institute of India and the National Law University. UTT chairman Curtis Manchoon and his wife will also be on the mission, and UTT is carded to sign a MOU with the Pandit Deendayal Petroleum University (PDPU). Manchoon will also be meeting with the Enterprise Development Institute to discuss the training of Trinidad and Tobago nationals in enterprise development skills, as well as meetings with the Indian Institute of Management and Indian Institute of Technology.
